items.goalPreference: Goals are invitations to explore. The target matters, but the route should stay playful and experimental so better solutions can emerge.
items.goalComms: Open with possibility, then co-create a direction: 'What could this become?' 'What would a bold first version look like?' Agree a simple test and a decision point.
items.feedbackStyle: Use curiosity-led feedback. Start with what is working, then ask for their view first. Offer constraints as design challenges, not restrictions.
items.watchouts: Can chase novelty and skip consolidation. Protect against too many parallel ideas by time-boxing exploration and insisting on one clear next commitment.

items.goalPreference: Goals should move and breathe. Plans are hypotheses, not contracts. Learning in motion is the point, so flexibility is part of the goal.
items.goalComms: Set a direction and give permission to adapt: 'Here is the outcome, adjust the method as you learn.' Use short checkpoints and ask, 'What are you noticing now?'
items.feedbackStyle: Feedback works best as rapid loops. Keep it short, specific, and immediate. Praise smart adaptation, then refine one thing to try next.
items.watchouts: Can drift or keep options open too long. Protect against endless adjustment by agreeing what must stay stable and what is allowed to flex.

items.goalPreference: Goals should feel alive and urgent. Motivation rises when the aim is meaningful, the standard is high, and progress is visible.
items.goalComms: Use energising language and momentum markers: 'Here is the standard.' 'Here is the next push.' Show progress quickly and celebrate small wins.
items.feedbackStyle: Deliver feedback with pace and belief. Keep it direct and optimistic. Use a challenge tone, then confirm recovery and sustainability.
items.watchouts: Can overpush and miss fatigue signals. Protect against burnout by building recovery into the plan and checking capacity before raising pace.

items.goalPreference: Goals work when they strengthen belonging and shared purpose. Commitment increases when people feel seen, heard, and aligned.
items.goalComms: Link goals to the group: 'This is why it matters to us.' Invite dialogue, then close with clarity: 'Here is what we are committing to together.'
items.feedbackStyle: Use warm clarity. Start with acknowledgement, then be specific about the behaviour. Ask how they want feedback delivered, then keep it consistent.
items.watchouts: Can avoid hard calls or over-consult. Protect against fuzzy accountability by naming roles, decisions, and boundaries kindly but firmly.

items.goalPreference: Goals should be coordinated so timing, roles, and handovers are smooth. Progress is built through rhythm and alignment across people.
items.goalComms: Make the goal operational: 'Who owns what?' 'What is the handover?' 'When do we check in?' Use brief, regular updates and visible shared tracking.
items.feedbackStyle: Feedback is best delivered through systems. Point to the agreed standard, then the specific interface to improve. Keep it practical and role-based.
items.watchouts: Can become a bottleneck or over-coordinate. Protect against meeting creep by using minimum viable alignment and clear decision ownership.

items.goalPreference: Goals should be structured with priorities, milestones, and a clear definition of success. Clarity reduces stress and increases execution quality.
items.goalComms: State the outcome, sequence the steps, and define 'done'. Use written summaries, clear decision points, and explicit trade-offs.
items.feedbackStyle: Feedback should be specific, behavioural, and tied to the plan. Offer one or two precise adjustments and confirm what stays the same.
items.watchouts: Can become rigid if conditions change. Protect against over-control by building in review points and asking, 'What would make this plan obsolete?'

items.goalPreference: Goals should be sustainable and steady. Progress comes from consistency, emotional regulation, and repeatable routines under pressure.
items.goalComms: Use calm, grounded language: 'Here is the next stable step.' Keep changes small and explain the why. Confirm safety and psychological steadiness.
items.feedbackStyle: Feedback lands best when it is private, calm, and respectful. Focus on one improvement, then reinforce what they are already doing well.
items.watchouts: Can delay escalation or avoid conflict. Protect against issues leaking sideways by naming tensions early and pairing calm with clear next steps.

items.goalPreference: Goals should be crisp, measurable, and action-led. They want decisions, commitments, and accountability that drives progress.
items.goalComms: Be direct: 'This is the target.' 'This is the deadline.' 'You own this.' Use clear decision rules and define what success looks like.
items.feedbackStyle: Feedback should be blunt but fair. Lead with the key point, then give one actionable instruction. Confirm autonomy and authority to act.
items.watchouts: Can become overly directive or reduce psychological safety. Protect against bluntness by asking one good question before closing: 'What am I missing?'

items.goalPreference: Goals should be precise, risk-aware, and standards-led. They prefer controlled execution, quality thresholds, and clear measurement.
items.goalComms: Use evidence and safeguards: 'What is the exact objective?' 'How will we measure change?' Define standards, controls, and escalation routes.
items.feedbackStyle: Feedback should reference the standard and the evidence. Be specific about what is acceptable, what is not, and what to do next.
items.watchouts: Can become overly risk-averse and slow progress. Protect against stagnation by separating non-negotiables from preferences and offering a safe pathway forward.
